posts.name: Caleb Piña
posts.cooked: Does anyone know what is a good way or app to make a good electrical diagram?

posts.name: freddie s
posts.cooked: As much as I dislike it, KiCAD is quite effective for creating electrical wiring diagrams. However, it’s not cloud-based or collaborative, meaning each project must be completed individually. Tools like Figma, Canva, and Google Slides have been mentioned as alternatives, though their capabilities may vary. Best of luck with your project!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: blue loctite does NOT taste good

posts.name: Caleb Piña
posts.cooked: Thank you. I'm handling it on my own; there won't be any issues.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: I would suggest getting a free (sponsored) copy of AutoCAD 2D. It is the industry standard drawing package for making wiring drawings and is better suited to drawing wiring diagrams than generic drawing programs. I was just using it for exactly this purpose earlier this morning. I believe that FRC teams can also get a free copy of AutoCAD Electrical but many of the extra features are really only useful for those doing mass manufacturing. Years ago, I tried to use KiCAD to make an electrical drawing for FRC robots because I wanted to exploit the 'rubberbanding' feature found in KiCAD (and Altium). Unfortunately, I found that the time required to make the symbols for all the components and other setup tasks required made it very time-consuming and impractical. Modifying the symbols to fit the application was also cumbersome. All programs like KiCAD and Altium that are meant for electronic circuit board (PCB) design will have the same advantages and disadvantages. I just found a cloud-based electrical CAD program, Capital X. They appear to offer licenses for students and educators (see FAQ section of second link). Cloud-native Capital X Panel Designer SaaS offering gives individual designers or small teams an affordable yet powerful electrical design solution.

posts.name: Caleb Piña
posts.cooked:
The assistant will perform the following steps: 1. **Remove HTML Tags**: Strip away the `

` tag since it's only used for formatting. 2. **Correct Spelling**: Change "definetly" to "definitely" to fix the spelling mistake. 3. **Format the Text**: Ensure the result is a single, coherent sentence. **Final Output:** "Will definitely check it out, thanks."

posts.name: Raymond
posts.cooked: Darw.io is a really nice web app for it. It connects to Google Drive and is collaborative.
Draw.io looks great. You can also get a bit fancier and use the images prepared by the team responsible for the 2025 Unofficial FRC Control System Diagrams.
We’ve used excalidraw to make diagrams like the one here at drive.google.com/file/d/1zfYqLdwT_1B9t92o7QsDoBC2Qs8EvY-t/view.

link_counts.title: Excalidraw | Hand-drawn look & feel • Collaborative • Secure

posts.name: Taiki Rogers
posts.cooked: It is very annoying, but if you're collaborating with others, I’ve used Google Drawings for such tasks in the past. This is ours for the 2025 season.

+1 for AutoCAD 2D. At work, we primarily use AutoCAD for electrical drawings. However, AutoCAD Electrical is mainly used for standard symbols and other features that typically involve applications more suited for robotics teams. Previously, I created drawings in regular AutoCAD for school projects.
